events.originalText: Himeji Castle (pictured), the largest and most visited Japanese castle, re-opened after five years of restoration work.
events.subtitle: Himeji Castle
events.headline: Himeji Castle re-opens after five years of restoration work

events.originalText: A failure of the dam holding Situ Gintung, an artificial lake in Tangerang, Indonesia, caused floods that killed at least 100 people.
events.subtitle: Situ Gintung
events.headline: Dam failure in Tangerang, Indonesia, kills at least 100 people

events.originalText: Second Intifada: A suicide bomber killed around 30 Israeli civilians and injured about 140 others in Netanya, triggering Operation Defensive Shield, a large-scale counter-terrorist military incursion into the West Bank.
events.subtitle: Second Intifada
events.headline: Suicide bomber kills 30 Israeli civilians in Netanya

events.originalText: During the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia, an Army of Yugoslavia unit shot down a U.S. Air Force F-117 stealth aircraft.
events.subtitle: NATO bombing of Yugoslavia
events.headline: Yugoslav unit shoots down U.S. Air Force F-117 stealth aircraft

events.originalText: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the drug sildenafil, better known by the trade name Viagra, for use as a treatment for erectile dysfunction, the first pill to be approved for this condition in the United States.
events.subtitle: Food and Drug Administration
events.headline: FDA approves Viagra for erectile dysfunction treatment

events.originalText: The Solidarity movement in Poland staged a warning strike, the largest in the history of the Eastern Bloc, in which at least 12 million Poles walked off their jobs for four hours.
events.subtitle: Solidarity (Polish trade union)
events.headline: Solidarity movement in Poland stages warning strike

events.originalText: Brothers Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt failed in their attempt to corner the world silver market, causing panic in commodity and futures exchanges.
events.subtitle: Nelson Bunker Hunt
events.headline: Hunt brothers fail to corner world silver market

events.originalText: Two Boeing 747 airliners collided on a foggy runway  at Los Rodeos Airport on the island of Tenerife, killing 583 people in the worst aircraft accident in aviation history
events.subtitle: Boeing 747
events.headline: Two Boeing 747 airliners collide in Tenerife, killing 583

events.originalText: The Washington Metro, the second-busiest rapid transit system in the U.S., opened to commuters.
events.subtitle: Washington Metro
events.headline: Washington Metro opens to commuters

events.originalText: Construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System, an oil pipeline spanning the length of Alaska, began.
events.subtitle: Construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System
events.headline: Construction begins on Trans-Alaska Pipeline System

events.originalText: The 9.2 Mw Good Friday earthquake, the strongest in U.S. history, and subsequent tsunamis devastated Anchorage, Alaska, killing over 130 people.
events.subtitle: Moment magnitude scale
events.headline: Good Friday earthquake devastates Anchorage, Alaska

events.originalText: Nikita Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, assumed the office of premier.
events.subtitle: Nikita Khrushchev
events.headline: Khrushchev assumes office of premier in Soviet Union

events.originalText: World War II: The United States Army Air Forces began Operation Starvation, laying naval mines in many of Japan's vital water routes and ports to disrupt enemy shipping.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Operation Starvation disrupts Japan's shipping routes

events.originalText: World War II: A group of Serbian-nationalist officers of the Royal Yugoslav Air Force carried out a coup d'état after Yugoslavia joined the Axis powers.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Yugoslav Air Force officers carry out coup d'état

events.originalText: Mary Mallon (pictured), the first person to be identified as an asymptomatic carrier of typhoid fever, was placed into quarantine in New York City, where she spent the rest of her life.
events.subtitle: Mary Mallon
events.headline: Mary Mallon placed into quarantine as typhoid carrier

events.originalText: Philippine–American War: American forces defeated troops commanded by Philippine president Emilio Aguinaldo at the Battle of Marilao River.
events.subtitle: Philippine–American War
events.headline: American forces defeat Philippine troops at Marilao River

events.originalText: Outraged by a jury's decision to convict a man of manslaughter instead of murder, a mob in Cincinnati, Ohio, began three days of rioting.
events.subtitle: Manslaughter
events.headline: Riots erupt in Cincinnati over manslaughter conviction

events.originalText: San Diego, the first European settlement in present-day California, was incorporated as a city.
events.subtitle: San Diego
events.headline: San Diego incorporated as a city in California

events.originalText: At least 425 Texian prisoners of war were executed in the Goliad massacre, under orders from Mexican president Antonio López de Santa Anna.
events.subtitle: Republic of Texas
events.headline: 425 Texian prisoners executed in Goliad massacre

events.originalText: The first of four destructive earthquakes struck southern Italy, destroying an estimated 10,000 homes.
events.subtitle: 1638 Calabrian earthquakes
events.headline: Destructive earthquake strikes southern Italy
